headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Special Edition: Tiananmen Square. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: Fifteen years ago, China was still almost totally isolated from the rest of the world.Today, the encouragement of private enterprise, free markets, foreign investment, and the introduction of western products and ideas has made this country the pioneer in the communist world search for reform. But now, China`s reform program has run into trouble.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Inflation officially has been at the 20 percent level in recent months. Corruption has grown a great deal.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: These dislocations caused by an economy that is only half reformed, neither communist nor capitalist, have generated widespreadpublic discontent.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: CNN was in Beijing as public discontent led to demonstrations and one of the darkest moments in China`s history.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: In the dead of night, 2,000 students marched through the streets of Beijing, calling for democracy human rights and the resignation of theChinese government. Their destination: Tiananmen Square in the city center.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: Tiananmen Square is the government`s ceremonial center and one of the largest plazas in the world.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: It was here that the students placed a huge banner honoring the memory of Hu Yaobang, who died on Saturday in political disgrace purged bycommunist party hardliners two and a half years ago for his liberal views. To the students however, Hu represented hope for reform and change, hopes that to many Chinese have been dashed by recent government efforts to scale back economic and political liberalization. There has never been a challenge to the leadership of communist China like this one. In cities all across the country, crowds taking to the streets to demand democracy and freedom. In commemorating Hu`s death by demanding the implementation of the progressive policies he advocated, the students have put the government on the defensive, most notably by using tactics such as the peaceful sit-in that the authorities here have never seen.

utterances.speaker: PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Long live freedom! Long live freedom! Punish corrupt officials! Punish corrupt officials! Freedom of the speech! Freedom of thespeech!

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: Chinese leadership was divided on how to respond and attempted to limit the public`s awareness of the demonstrations.However, some journalists were sympathetic to the demonstrators.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: The students got a big boost when several official Chinese newspapers defied government orders and published accurate accounts of theevents of the past week.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: As public support grew; student activists encouraged the general population to join the call for reform.UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translator):  If you`re going to have a student movement, you must seek support from the workers and peasants. Only if they understand can we succeed.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: Again and again, the badly outnumbered police were overwhelmed and pushed aside.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: On May 4th, nineteen days after the protests began, tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on Tiananmen Square.May 4th was the anniversary of the 1919 student movement that led to the communist revolution.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: This was the demonstrator`s destination, Tiananmen Square, the heart of Beijing, the seat of the government.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: The scene at Tiananmen showed the depth of public discontent here now, over inflation, corruption and the lack of political freedom.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: One month into the demonstrations, The students sang the Internationale, the international communist anthem.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: On the eve of Mikhail Gorbachev`s visit, China`s rebellious students up the stakes in their confrontation with the government, adoptinga new set of tactics to force a faster pace of reform. Two hundred students started a hunger strike, marching through Beijing to downtown Tiananmen Square, vowing to stay without food until the authorities agreed to recognize their illegal students` federation.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: China`s leaders were scheduled to meet in Beijing with Mikhail Gorbachev to mend years of strife between the communist republics.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: With Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet Union`s pioneer of political reform due here on Monday, no one in the Chinese leadership wants him tohave a reception like this.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: The number of hunger strikers quickly grew.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: This is now the third day in which about a thousand students have been carrying out a hunger strike to press their demands fordemocracy. UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translator):  Gorbachev`s reforms have been extremely successful. So we hope his visit will help accelerate political reform in China.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: A growing number of those in the square are not students but journalists professional people and especially workers impatient forchange. For China`s leaders, there could not be a more embarrassing or frightening set of circumstances.

utterances.speaker: BERNARD SHAW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Now some thoughts, I came to cover a summit. I walked into a revolution, a massively peaceful statement by the people butstill a revolution.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: By May 19, an estimated 1.2 million demonstrators had gathered in Tiananmen Square.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: Huge crowds again serves through the center of Beijing, people from all walks of life, workers, taxi drivers, shopkeepers, even somepeasants from the countryside while lending their support to the hunger striker`s demand for freedom and democracy. At the same time, over a hundred thousand people demonstrated in Shanghai where 300 students had begun their own hunger strike.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: Government leaders visited the students to ask them to end their hunger strike.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You have every right to criticize us. I`m also not here to ask for your forgiveness this time.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: Communist Party Chief Zhao and Premier Li visiting Tiananmen Square to appeal for an end to the student hunger strike.Late in the evening, Premier Li appeared on nationwide television to announce that the situation was out of control and that the army was being called in to restore orders. LI PENG, PREMIER OF THE PEOPLE`S REPUBLIC OF CHINA (through translator):  The situation in Beijing is getting worse and it is going to bring out a nationwide riot if we don`t really do anything to crack to stop this situation.

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: Communist Party Chief Zhao, a liberal who had sympathized with the students, being enforced to resign.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: There is word authorities decided he had to go because he refused to agree to use force against the students.

utterances.speaker: LI
utterances.sentences: For a month, the government has taken very calm and tolerant attitude towards the students` demonstration. We did this because we love ourstudents.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: Premier Li Peng claimed that the students were under the influence of a few troublemakers, and those on hunger strike were`hostages". The People`s Liberation Army was ordered in to clear the square.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Masters of demonstrators marched out of Beijing and rode in cars to the west. Before dawn, more than one hundred thousand were on theoutskirts of the city, taking the confrontation to the troops, not waiting for the army to reach town.

utterances.speaker: SHAW
utterances.sentences: The People`s Liberation Army blocked by the people. The troops cannot move to clear Tiananmen Square.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: This is CNN`s Prime News. And in Beijing, Bernard Shaw.

utterances.speaker: SHAW
utterances.sentences: Let`s go quickly to Jeanne Moos in Tiananmen Square -- Jeanne.

utterances.speaker: JEANNE MOOS, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Bernie, we don`t have any real hard information down here. The same announcement keeps coming over the PAsystem. It`s an official announcement signed by the premier of China, according to the announcer. And it talks about martial law being imposed here in Tiananmen Square. It was a night of tension, a break of celebration in the morning of uncertainty.

utterances.speaker: SHAW
utterances.sentences: Jeanne, Jeanne?

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Bernie?

utterances.speaker: SHAW
utterances.sentences: I`m being told that the government officials are coming into the CNN control room now. This man with a piece of paper in his hand. I`m certainthat is not a party invitation. Okay, let me quickly tell you what this official is saying: if you do not obey the orders, you will not be allowed to come home. This official on the right side of your right side of your screen saying to CNN, if you do not obey the --

utterances.speaker: NARRATOR
utterances.sentences: The Chinese government ordered all foreign media to stop broadcasting.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You have him call us properly and explain to us what is happening here. If you cannot give us an explanation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Moment, please?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Fine.

utterances.speaker: SHAW
utterances.sentences: We`re told that President George Herbert Walker Bush is watching what`s happening. President Bush is saying, quote, word of the newsblackout is very disturbing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Our government led me to tell you now stop your transmission.
